coredata.dc:title: Construction Product Declarations and Sustainable Development Goals for Small and Medium Construction Enterprises

Collin, Christine
Linnet, Andreas
coredata.dc:description: In recent years some cases have shown a decrease in emissions related to energy consumption (i.e. CO2/kWh) because of green energy transition and focus on energy efficiency that consequently means that emissions from building materials in a building life cycle perspective are becoming relatively larger. The focus on reducing emissions is creating a shift from a use phase perspective into a more holistic approach using a life cycle perspective. The building industry needs transparency of its environmental impacts to make informed decisions. Nevertheless, many material and product manufacturers have not produced Product Environmental Footprint (PEF), Environmental Product Declarations (EPD) or similar evaluations of the environmental life cycle impact. This study assesses how small and medium enterprise (SME) developers of building products can start their Life Cycle Engineering (LCE) journey by addressing the relevant Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), defined by the United Nations, and which of the 169 targets material and product manufacturers have a direct or indirect impact on. The study describes each relevant target and their relation to life cycle engineering.

Product Environmental Footprint (PEF)
Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs)

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Available online at www.sciencedirect.com 2212-8271 Â© 2018 The Authors. Published by Elsevier B.V. This is an open access article under the CC BY-NC-ND license (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/). Peer-review under responsibility of the scientific committee of the 25th CIRP Life Cycle Engineering (LCE) Conference doi: 10.1016/j.procir.2017.12.011 Procedia CIRP 69 ( 2018 ) 54 â€“ 58 ScienceDirect 25th CIRP Life Cycle Engineering (LCE) Conference, 30 April â€“ 2 May 2018, Copenhagen, Denmark Construction Product Declarations and Sustainable Development Goals for Small and Medium Construction Enterprises Andreas Q. Sechera*, Christine Collina, Andreas Linnetb aRamboll A/S, Hannemanns AllÃ© 53, 2300 Copenhagen, Denmark bRamboll Environmental & Health, Hannemanns AllÃ© 53, 2300 Copenhagen, Denmark * Corresponding author. Tel.: + 45 5161 2270; fax: + 45 5161 1001.. E-mail address: aqs@ramboll.dk Abstract In recent years some cases have shown a decrease in emissions related to energy consumption (i.e. CO2/kWh) because of green energy transition and focus on energy efficiency that consequently means that emissions from building materials in a building life cycle perspective are becoming relatively larger. The focus on reducing emissions is creating a shift from a use phase perspective into a more holistic approach using a life cycle perspective. The building industry needs transparency of its environmental impacts to make informed decisions. Nevertheless, many material and product manufacturers have not produced Product Environmental Footprint (PEF), Environmental Product Declarations (EPD) or similar evaluations of the environmental life cycle impact. This study assesses how small and medium enterprise (SME) developers of building products can start their Life Cycle Engineering (LCE) journey by addressing the relevant Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), defined by the United Nations, and which of the 169 targets material and product manufacturers have a direct or indirect impact on. The study describes each relevant target and their relation to life cycle engineering. Â© 2017 The Authors. Published by Elsevier B.V. Peer-review under responsibility of the scientific committee of the 25th CIRP Life Cycle Engineering (LCE) Conference. Keywords: Life Cycle Management, Environmental Product Declaration (EPD), Product Environmental Footprint (PEF), Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) 1. Introduction In the early 1980s the World Commission on Environment and Development was asked by the General Assembly of the United Nations to make â€œa global agenda for changeâ€� [1]. In 1987 the report â€˜Our Common FutureÂ´, also known as the Brundtland Report, was published and sustainability was positioned centrally in the discussion on world development [2]. Thirty years later the ecological footprint index (coupled with the human development) shows that countries such as Denmark overshoot the sustainable world ecological and biological capacity by at least a factor of 3 [3]. The necessary reduction in greenhouse gasses, increase in world population projection and increase in global material use due to an increase in middle-class population means that the technology needs to be eight times as environmentally friendly as it is today [4]. A global challenge that must be addressed and the construction industry have a significant impact. The construction industry share of extracted materials from Earthâ€™s biological or mineral resources is known to be around 44% [5]. As an example, the construction industry is the largest user of natural resources and produces massive amounts of waste in the UK [6]. Through the past fifty years the energy consumption in new buildings in Denmark has been reduced from approximately 350 kWh/m2 to 40 kWh/m2 [7]. Together with the more environmental friendly energy production for heat and electricity the development, manufacturing, transport, disposal and recycling of building materials account for an Â© 2018 The Authors. Published by Elsevier B.V. This is an open access article under the CC BY-NC-ND license (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/). Peer-review under responsibility of the scientifi c committee of the 25th CIRP Life Cycle Engineering (LCE) Conference 55 Andreas Q. Secher et al. / Procedia CIRP 69 ( 2018 ) 54 â€“ 58 increasing share of the new building's overall resource and environmental life cycle impact. Two main methods of quantifying the environmental impacts of construction products, Environmental Product Declarations (EPD) and Product Environmental Footprint (PEF), are described as Ramboll acknowledges these as some of the main declarations on the market for construction products. However, as they both can be expensive to procure, especially for smaller businesses, this resource is intended to help the construction industry start its journey towards sustainable practice through inspiration from the relevant UN Sustainable Development Goals and related. The work conducted in this study is produced because it is Rambollâ€™s view that construction material and will play an increasingly central role to fulfil the global goals. 2. LCA in the Danish building industry Ramboll experiences an increased interest in sustainability assessments, for example of urban districts, buildings and different building materials. In years the focus in the building industry has been on energy consumption but because of scarce material resource and embedded energy, materials potentials of improvement have become a focus area. In fig. 1 are kg CO2-eq pr. m2 pr. year displayed for four selected Ramboll DGNB certified buildings over a timeframe of 50 years. The figure shows a higher impact from materials compared to heat consumption from district heating. The emissions from district heating in the Danish DGNB manual version 2014 is even with a static 50 year projection, which means that the actual emission from heat in reality will be lower than seen in fig. 1. Fig. 1. Global Warming Potential for four selected Ramboll DGNB certified buildings where an LCA has been conducted showing their impact on construction and heat requirement over 50 years. In Denmark the projection towards 2050 shows an increased share of renewable energy in the energy mix, and in particular a fast change for district heating systems [8]. In addition, by 2020 over half of Danish electricity will be provided by wind power alone [8], and throughout Europe there are currently plans in motion to reduce the use of fossil fuels dramatically [9]. In evaluating the emissions from energy production projection towards 2050 against the target of a fossil-free European energy mix by 2050, the embedded energy and emissions in construction materials and products will have an increasingly relatively larger environmental impact in the construction industry. Thus, it is Rambolls view that environmental impacts related to construction materials and circularity will increase in the years to come. 3. Construction Product Declarations Sustainability objectives differ for each company and institution depending on how they impact society and the environment. Whether private or public sector, the challenge is to identify and integrate more holistically sustainable approaches to achieving business goals and economic health. Many companies face demands for documented environmental performance from authorities and customers. Other companies see commercial benefits in enhancing the transparency of their respective products and providing more sustainable products than their competitors. 3.1. Environmental Product Declaration (EPD) EPDs are based on the European Standard EN 15804, and most are all third party verified [10]. Ramboll continuously works with third party verified EPDs in order to help our clients meet a wide array of business objectives, primarily market differentiation and product stewardship. EPDs are an internationally recognized standardized framework to assess the environmental impacts of materials, components or the full product life cycle assessment (LCA). EPDs are standardized calculations with a third-party review, which enhances the transparency of the information made available this way. It is Rambollâ€™s experience that EPDs are primarily used for building classification systems such as DGNB, purchasing and product selection and product development. EPDs are a valuable tool as they serve to provide a verified overview of environmental performance, and in the case of DGNB, it also assists in gaining points in the building classification system. 3.2. Product Environmental Footprint (PEF) Product Environmental Footprint is a multi-criteria measure of a productâ€™s or serviceâ€™s environmental performance throughout its entire life cycle. Upon conducting a PEF, the information is produced with the goal of benchmarking as well as identifying key areas of interest in the various production stages, also including supply chain activities [11]. These areas are then targeted in order to reduce their environmental impacts. Thus, a PEF also utilizes the holistic view that Ramboll always applies when working with sustainability. It is important to always assess the robustness of a given PEF model with regard to completeness checks, sensitivity checks and consistency checks. A model is never stronger than the quality 0.0E+00 1.0E+00 2.0E+00 3.0E+00 4.0E+00 5.0E+00 6.0E+00 7.0E+00 8.0E+00 9.0E+00 Building I Building II Building III Building IV kg C O 2- eq p r. m 2 pr . y ea r Global warming potential - 50 year life cycle period Construction Heat requirement 56 Andreas Q. Secher et al. / Procedia CIRP 69 ( 2018 ) 54 â€“ 58 of data upon which it is built. When the robustness of the PEF is assessed, the potential improvements such as cleaner technologies, changes in product design, implementing an environmental management system (EMAS, ISO14001) will be recommended and the potential improvements quantified. 3.3. Comparison of product declarations Both methods can be used to evaluate and quantify the environmental performance of, for example but not limited to, construction materials. However, a comparison between them is not possible even though they share some of the same impact categories such as CO2-eq and ozone depletion. Even though they share the LCA approach, PEFs do currently not have a European standard such as the EN15804, and thus rely heavily on data that has otherwise been peer reviewed and accepted. Some articles even raise a critique that â€œPEFs are adding unrealistic requirements, burden and costs to LCA application for business and SMEâ€™s without adding valueâ€� [12]. The holistic LCE approach, supported by the relevant SDG targets, removes the unnecessary burdens from the industry, and enables their journey towards sustainable practise through inspiration from the relevant Sustainable Development Goals. 4. SDGs for material and production manufacturers in the construction industry Construction material and product manufacturers have a significant influence and impact on reaching a range of targets within the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). In contrast to the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs), which range from halving extreme poverty to halting the spread of HIV/AIDS and providing universal primary education, the SDGs address the responsibilities, and direct and indirect impacts the developed countries have. The UNâ€™s SDGs will complete the work begun with the MDGs. Supported by the more business focused UN Global Compact, there is a growing need to focus and measure sustainability on a global and local scale using methods such as Life Cycle Assessments [13]. Fig. 2. UN Sustainable Development Goals This chapter pinpoints what targets can be addressed as an initial start on working towards reaching the goals and sustainability demands the construction industry is facing. 4.1. Direct impact The direct impact is, for the purpose of construction product developers, defined in this article as â€˜resulting impacts from the production and use of a given construction productâ€™. The construction material and product manufacturers have a direct influence, as identified by Ramboll, on 7 of the 17 SDGs as seen in fig. 3. Fig. 3. Sustainable Development Goals for construction material and product manufacturers. The SDGs where construction material and product manufacturers have a direct impact have been assessed by investigating all 169 targets. Notice that targets that is marked with * is where EPDs and PEFs (and product life cycle assessments) can measure performance. Below are the relevant SDG targets that have been identified to have a direct impact: 1. Target 3.9) By 2030, substantially reduce the number of deaths and illnesses from hazardous chemicals and air, water, and soil pollution and contamination 2. Target 6.3) By 2030, improve water quality by reducing pollution, eliminating dumping and minimizing release of hazardous chemicals and materials, halving the proportion of untreated wastewater and substantially increasing recycling and safe reuse globally 3. Target 6.4) By 2030, substantially increase water-use efficiency across all sectors and ensure sustainable withdrawals and supply of freshwater to address water scarcity and substantially reduce the number of people suffering from water scarcity 4. *Target 7.3) By 2030, double the global rate of improvement in energy efficiency 5. *Target 8.4) Improve progressively, through 2030, global resource efficiency in consumption and production and endeavour to decouple economic growth from environmental degradation, in accordance with the 10-year framework of programmes on sustainable consumption and production, with developed countries taking the lead 6. *Target 9.4) By 2030, upgrade infrastructure and retrofit industries to make them sustainable, with increased resource-use efficiency and greater adoption of clean and environmentally sound technologies and industrial 57 Andreas Q. Secher et al. / Procedia CIRP 69 ( 2018 ) 54 â€“ 58 processes, with all countries taking action in accordance with their respective capabilities 7. Target 11.6) By 2030, reduce the adverse per capita environmental impact of cities, by paying special attention to air quality and municipal and other waste management 8. *Target 12.2) By 2030, achieve the sustainable management and efficient use of natural resources 9. Target 12.4) By 2020, achieve the environmentally sound management of chemicals and all wastes throughout their life cycle, in accordance with agreed international frameworks, and significantly reduce their release to air, water and soil in order to minimize their adverse impacts on human health and the environment 10. *Target 12.5) By 2030, substantially reduce waste generation through prevention, reduction, recycling and reuse 4.2. Indirect impact The indirect impact is, for the purpose of construction product developers, defined in this article as â€˜impacts following effects of the construction product through its value chain or impact not aimed at primarilyâ€™. Below the relevant SDG targets that have an indirect impact are identified: 11. Target 3.4) By 2030, reduce by one third pre-mature mortality from non-communicable diseases (NCDs) through prevention and treatment, and promote mental health and wellbeing. 12. Target 6.6) By 2020, protect and restore water-related ecosystems, including mountains, forests, wetlands, rivers, aquifers and lakes 13. Target 12.6) Encourage companies, especially large and transnational companies, to adopt sustainable practices and to integrate sustainability information into their reporting cycle 14. Target 12.7) Promote public procurement practices that are sustainable, in accordance with national policies and priorities 15. Target 14.1) By 2025, prevent and significantly reduce marine pollution of all kinds, in particular from land-based activities, including marine debris and nutrient pollution 16. Target 15.1) By 2020, ensure the conservation, restoration and sustainable use of terrestrial and inland freshwater ecosystems and their services, in particular forests, wetlands, mountains and drylands, in line with obligations under international agreements 17. Target 15.5) Take urgent and significant action to reduce the degradation of natural habitats, halt the loss of biodiversity and, by 2020, protect and prevent the extinction of threatened species 18. Target 17.16) Enhance the global partnership for sustainable development, complemented by multi- stakeholder partnerships that mobilize and share knowledge, expertise, technology and financial resources, to support the achievement of the sustainable development goals in all countries, in particular developing countries 5. Discussion 5.1. SDGs and Product Declarations The SDGs require a systemic approach and to provide consumers with adequate information through, amongst others, standards and labels and engaging in sustainable public procurement [14]. The Environmental Product Declaration and Product Environmental Footprint are labels or standards that focus on supplying adequate information with a systemic approach to emissions such as CO2 equivalents and ozone depletion. These standards could be used to document the construction material and product manufacturersâ€™ impact on the SDGs and support their targets, as listed in table 1. The indicators from the SDGs are taken from the official revised list of global SDG Indicators [15]. Table 1. EPD/PEF usefulness in connection to relevant SDG targets and indicators for construction product developers. Targets Indicators from SDG EPD/PEF Target 7.3 Energy intensity measured in terms of primary energy and GDP Partly useful as SDG indicator Target 8.4 and Target 12.2 8.4.1 Material footprint, material footprint per capita, and material footprint per GDP 8.4.2 Domestic material consumption, domestic material consumption per capita, and domestic material consumption per GDP Partly useful as SDG indicator Target 9.4 CO2 emission per unit of value added Useful as SDG indicator Target 12.5 National recycling rate, tons of material recycled Useful as SDG indicator The Green Construction Board has identified seven tips that can directly help the construction industry to reduce life cycle emissions [16] which can be used as a beginning if EPD/PEF are not currently affordable. The seven tips are: communicate end of life options, consider take-back schemes, consider offering your product as a service, minimise waste during manufacture, optimise packaging, design for remanufacture and optimise secondary materials. Adding to the importance of transparency in the construction industry and life cycle engineering we would like to quote UN goal 12, why it matters; â€œItâ€™s in businessesâ€™ interest to find new solutions that enable sustainable consumption and production patterns. A better understanding of environmental and social impacts of products and services is needed, both of product life cycles and how these are affected by use within lifestyles. Identifying â€œhot spotsâ€� within the value chain where interventions have the greatest potential to improve the environmental and social impact of the system as a whole is a crucial first step. Businesses can also use their innovative power to design solutions that can both enable and inspire individuals to lead more sustainable lifestyles, reducing impacts and improving well-being.â€� [14] By generating transparency of the environmental impact such as through EPDs or PEFs value can be added to the construction industry. However, as pointed out in the quote and 58 Andreas Q. Secher et al. / Procedia CIRP 69 ( 2018 ) 54 â€“ 58 through the other targets discussed in the previous section, a better understanding of the social impacts and businessesâ€™ innovative power to design solutions that enable, amongst others, sustainable life cycles, reduction in impacts and improvements in well-being, is also necessary to address for construction product developers. 5.2. The holistic approach of Life Cycle Engineering It is Rambollâ€™s experience that construction product developers want to look beyond product declarations and is also investigating how products comply with sustainability certification standards such as DGNB, LEED and BREEAM. Beyond these certification standards Ramboll applies a holistic LCE approach when assessing sustainability. It is also Rambollâ€™s task to include life cycle cost, chemicals in the context of the specific project and a focus on human well-being and social impact. Ramboll addresses components, products and services using LCE through LCA and Life Cycle Cost (LCC) comparisons, adjusted to the need of the client. The efforts are always adjusted to the defined task and often the initial work kickstarts a longer LCE journey where both complete LCAs and EPDs ends up being requested by the clients. However, Ramboll is often tasked with the job of having to identify the most sustainable solutions to a given product or service. These requests rarely have an extended time frame, thus a method for quickly screening manufacturers and companies in general have been implemented. Basically, relevant companies are screened for publicly available information regarding important topics: x Emissions of volatile Organic compounds x CO2 emissions pr. relevant unit x Any environmental management system (if implemented, which one?) x Any relevant certifications (Cradle to Cradle etc.) x Corporate Social Responsibility (If at all, how do they work with it on a daily and yearly basis) Ramboll gather information on these topics, to evaluate the product so that companies overall environmental impacts transparency becomes apparent, thus enabling our clients to take informed decisions on which companies and products to initiate corporation with. A huge barrier for industries to adapt an LCA approach is the often-excessive costs that can be associated with a full product LCA. Through Rambollâ€™s LCE method it is ensured that the benefits from a holistic view of a given product are achieved at the pace and cost that is sustainable for the client. 6. Conclusion Sustainability objectives differ for each company and institution depending on how the businesses impact society and the environment. Sustainable Development Goals and the relevant targets provide an excellent point of departure for the sustainability journey that all manufacturers can have the opportunity to commence. LCE offers a sustainable holistic view of not only a production phase, but the life cycle impacts of a given product, design, or service. It is well known that a full LCA on a product can be a financial burden, especially for small businesses, and therefore acts as a prohibiting factor. This resource has highlighted the most relevant targets within the Sustainable Development Goals for small and medium building product manufacturers and can be used to start the journey of successfully working towards sustainability. LCE offers a sustainable holistic view of not only a production phase, but the life cycle impacts of a given product, design, or service. It is well known that a full LCA on a product can be a financial burden, especially for small businesses, and therefore acts as a prohibiting factor. This resource has highlighted the most relevant targets within the Sustainable Development Goals for small and medium building product manufacturers and can be used to start the journey of successfully working towards sustainability. ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: In recent years some cases have shown a decrease in emissions related to energy consumption (i.e. CO2/kWh) because of green energy transition and focus on energy efficiency that consequently means that emissions from building materials in a building life cycle perspective are becoming relatively larger. The focus on reducing emissions is creating a shift from a use phase perspective into a more holistic approach using a life cycle perspective.

The building industry needs transparency of its environmental impacts to make informed decisions. Nevertheless, many material and product manufacturers have not produced Product Environmental Footprint (PEF), Environmental Product Declarations (EPD) or similar evaluations of the environmental life cycle impact. This study assesses how small and medium enterprise (SME) developers of building products can start their Life Cycle Engineering (LCE) journey by addressing the relevant Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), defined by the United Nations, and which of the 169 targets material and product manufacturers have a direct or indirect impact on. The study describes each relevant target and their relation to life cycle engineering.
